title: Corporate Watch
text:
In Quarterly Profit

Ciena Corp. shares fell 11% Monday after the networking-systems company reported lower earnings for its fiscal first quarter.

The Hanover, Md., company logged earnings of $45.8 million for the quarter ended Jan. 29, compared with $55.3 million a year earlier.

Ciena said its operating expenses increased 15% year over year. Revenue rose 12% to $844.4 million.

Ciena said strong order growth gives the company confidence that it would hit the revenue growth expected for the fiscal year. The company has said it expects revenue to grow by 11% to 13% in fiscal 2022.

Shares of Ciena closed at $58.76.

-- Will Feuer

---

CORNERSTONE BUILDING

Building-Products

Maker Sells Itself

Cornerstone Building Brands Inc. agreed to sell itself to private-equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice LLC in a deal that values Cornerstone at about $3.13 billion.

CD&R owned about 49% of the company's shares outstanding before the deal.

Shareholders of Cornerstone, a manufacturer and marketer of exterior building products, will receive $24.65 for each share owned. That price marks a 16% premium to the company's closing stock price on Friday and a 75% premium over the closing price on Feb. 4, before news reports suggested a deal could be in works.

The deal is expected to close in the second or third quarter of 2022, the companies said.

-- Will Feuer

---

HAWAIIAN HOLDINGS

Carrier to Offer

New Flight Routes

Hawaiian Holdings Inc. said that it is resuming nonstop service between Oakland, Calif., and Kona on the island of Hawaii and adding a second daily flight between San Francisco and Honolulu.

The Hawaiian airline said service between Oakland and Kona, which last operated in the summer of 2016, will be available between June 15 and Sept. 6. Service between San Francisco and Honolulu will run between May 15 and Aug 1.

The company is also offering daily nonstop flights between Los Angeles and Maui from June 11 through Aug. 15.

Shares of Hawaiian Holdings fell 11% amid a broader selloff in travel and airline stocks.

-- Denny Jacob

---

LIMELIGHT NETWORKS

Deal to Buy Yahoo's

Edgecast Is Set

Limelight Networks Inc. agreed to buy Yahoo's Edgecast Inc. unit in an all-stock deal that values the provider of edge security, content delivery and video services at about $300 million.

Limelight said it will issue about 72.2 million shares to Yahoo, majority owned by private-equity firm Apollo Global Management Inc., resulting in Yahoo owning about 31.9% of the combined company at closing.

Apollo bought Yahoo last year for $5 billion from Verizon Communications Inc., with Verizon keeping a 10% stake.

Limelight, a Tempe, Ariz., provider of content-delivery network services, said the deal will create a software provider with 2021 annual revenue topping $500 million.

Limelight said it plans to rebrand as Edgio, with the combined company operating under the new moniker upon closing of the deal, slated for the second half of the year.

-- Colin Kellaher
